head.title: Ford Adds to Warranty On Engine-Gasket Flaw

hedline.hl1: Ford Adds to Warranty On Engine-Gasket Flaw

abstract.p: Ford agrees to pay for head-gasket repairs to 1994-1995 rear-wheel-drive models that were not covered by earlier offer to owners of front-wheel-drive cars with defective gasket; Phil Edmonston of lemonaidcars.com Web site and Clarence M Ditlow of Center for Auto Safety say Ford should have extended warranty to 120,000 miles (S)

block.p: IN a move that consumer advocates say could benefit owners of all brands of vehicles, the Ford Motor Company has agreed to cover head-gasket repairs for some rear-wheel-drive cars with the 3.8-liter V-6 engine.

Ford had announced in February that it would pay for repairs on about 718,000 front-drive automobiles with that engine: the 1994-95 Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, the 1994 Lincoln Continental and the 1995 Ford Windstar. But the rear-drive cars -- Ford Mustangs, Mercury Cougars and Ford Thunderbirds from the 1994-95 model years -- were excluded. Some consumers were stuck with bills ranging from $1,600 for gasket repairs to $4,000 for destroyed engines.

IN a move that consumer advocates say could benefit owners of all brands of vehicles, the Ford Motor Company has agreed to cover head-gasket repairs for some rear-wheel-drive cars with the 3.8-liter V-6 engine.

Ford had announced in February that it would pay for repairs on about 718,000 front-drive automobiles with that engine: the 1994-95 Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, the 1994 Lincoln Continental and the 1995 Ford Windstar. But the rear-drive cars -- Ford Mustangs, Mercury Cougars and Ford Thunderbirds from the 1994-95 model years -- were excluded. Some consumers were stuck with bills ranging from $1,600 for gasket repairs to $4,000 for destroyed engines.

Ford changed its mind this spring, saying it now realizes that owners of those cars were also having problems. It is extending the head-gasket warranty on about 294,000 of the rear-drive cars and reimbursing owners who already paid for repairs.
A head gasket is a thin seal between the engine block and the cylinder head; if it fails, coolant can leak out or seep into mechanical components, potentially causing total engine failure.

Phil Edmonston, author of the annual ''Lemon-Aid Car Guide,'' said Ford's action was important to owners of other makes because it reinforced the idea that engines should not suffer major defects for at least 7 years or 100,000 miles. General Motors and Toyota have offered similar special policies to cover head-gasket defects.

Mr. Edmonston, who also has a Web site, www.lemonaidcars.com, said that having such a ''durability parameter'' would give consumers who have problems with other cars ammunition to use in small-claims court or in negotiations with car companies. In addition, Ford's action puts pressure on other automakers to follow suit.
One company that could feel such pressure is DaimlerChrysler. Some of its 2-liter 4-cylinder engines have also had head-gasket problems, which the company is covering case by case.

Under its new policy, Ford will extend to seven years or 100,000 miles, whichever comes first, the warranty on the head gaskets on the 3.8-liter V-6 in '94-'95 models. The normal warranty is 3 years or 36,000 miles.

The automaker will also reimburse consumers who had those repairs done, even if the work was not done by a Ford dealer, a company spokesman, Mike Vaughn, said. There is no limit on the repair cost, and Ford will pay if a new engine was required. The policy also covers owners of used cars.

The letter being sent to consumers will tell those who already paid for repairs how they can apply for a refund. Those who purchased the vehicles used and do not receive a letter should contact a Ford dealer.

''Ford is taking a Band-Aid approach to it,'' said Clarence M. Ditlow of the Center for Auto Safety. ''They put on one Band-Aid to see if it would stop the bleeding. It didn't. Now they put on another one, a bigger Band-Aid. But what they need to do is have a comprehensive program.''
He said Ford should have extended the warranty to 120,000 miles, ''which is the average useful life of a vehicle today,'' and should have covered models predating 1994.

Mr. Ditlow and Mr. Edmonston want Ford to include '93 cars; Mr. Ditlow said he thought the problem dated as far back as '88 models. Mr. Vaughn said records showed there was no problem with earlier vehicles.

Although he urged Ford to cover '93 models, Mr. Edmonston said the company was responding in a generous, timely manner. He said DaimlerChrysler should do the same on 2-liter engines in the 1995-99 Neon, Dodge Stratus, Plymouth Breeze, Dodge Avenger and Chrysler Sebring. The problems are being dealt with case by case; the company has not extended the warranty.

A DaimlerChrysler spokesman, Mike Aberlich, said all owners were not being notified because ''it does not appear to be a universal problem.'' He added: ''That's not to say that we might not decide to do something in the future. We are still watching and analyzing it.''

Mr. Aberlich said DaimlerChrysler was reimbursing consumers for out-of-warranty repairs case by case when they called the company's toll-free assistance number -- (800) 992-1997 -- or went to dealerships. He said the dealers would consider factors including whether there was any evidence that the vehicle was abused.

One problem with DaimlerChrysler's policy is that owners who figure their warranty no longer applies and go to independent repair shops instead of to dealers might lose a chance for eventual reimbursement. ''They are penalized,'' Mr. Edmonston said.
